body:
I honestly can't find any mention of `--dry-run` outside of distutils, and even that seems to have problems:

http://mail.python.org/pipermail/distutils-sig/2010-April/016000.html

pandas uses setuptools or distribute to do the packaging, so probably the packaging people allowed that option to go by the wayside

Hi Anaphory, (or anyone else willing to follow up on this ticket,) From what I read at http://mail.python.org/pipermail/distutils-sig/2010-April/016000.html , the "--dry-run" option has to come _before_ the "install" command. So this: 
python setup.py -v install --dry-run --install-lib "~/python"
should actually do the install. But _this_: 
python setup.py -v --dry-run install --install-lib "~/python"
should not. Can you see if the above is true, on your system? If we're lucky, the problem is simply the order you passed the arguments in. In that case, we can close the ticket. If pandas is ignoring --dry-run , then, well, we might also want to close the ticket because as @wesm said, the option is very rarely used. But either way, we should find out if swapping the order of the arguments fixes the problem.
I don't know if `--dry-run` is supported by setuptools/distribute. If it's not, we should close this issue

It seems that `--dry-run` is an option of whatever handles the setup on this my machine (sorry I haven't looked into that yet), and shows up in `setup.py`'s help:

```
$ python setup.py --help
Common commands: (see '--help-commands' for more)

  setup.py build      will build the package underneath 'build/'
  setup.py install    will install the package

Global options:
  --verbose (-v)      run verbosely (default)
  --quiet (-q)        run quietly (turns verbosity off)
  --dry-run (-n)      don't actually do anything
  --help (-h)         show detailed help message
  --no-user-cfg       ignore pydistutils.cfg in your home directory
  --command-packages  list of packages that provide distutils commands

Information display options (just display information, ignore any commands)
  --help-commands     list all available commands
  --name              print package name
  --version (-V)      print package version
  --fullname          print <package name>-<version>
  --author            print the author's name
  --author-email      print the author's email address
  --maintainer        print the maintainer's name
  --maintainer-email  print the maintainer's email address
  --contact           print the maintainer's name if known, else the author's
  --contact-email     print the maintainer's email address if known, else the
                      author's
  --url               print the URL for this package
  --license           print the license of the package
  --licence           alias for --license
  --description       print the package description
  --long-description  print the long package description
  --platforms         print the list of platforms
  --classifiers       print the list of classifiers
  --keywords          print the list of keywords
  --provides          print the list of packages/modules provided
  --requires          print the list of packages/modules required
  --obsoletes         print the list of packages/modules made obsolete

usage: setup.py [global_opts] cmd1 [cmd1_opts] [cmd2 [cmd2_opts] ...]
   or: setup.py --help [cmd1 cmd2 ...]
   or: setup.py --help-commands
   or: setup.py cmd --help
```

When I run `python setup.py -v --dry-run install --install-lib "~/python"`, it does indeed nothing for the build process, as expected; it then ends with

```
warning: install_lib: 'build/lib.freebsd-9.0-RELEASE-amd64-2.7' does not exist -- no Python modules to install

creating build/bdist.freebsd-9.0-RELEASE-amd64
creating build/bdist.freebsd-9.0-RELEASE-amd64/egg
creating build/bdist.freebsd-9.0-RELEASE-amd64/egg/EGG-INFO
error: build/bdist.freebsd-9.0-RELEASE-amd64/egg/EGG-INFO/not-zip-safe: No such file or directory
```

when starting the install. When I run a proper build before that, `python setup.py build && python setup.py -v --dry-run install --install-lib "~/python"`, it seems to work in general. (That is, I currently get

```
building 'pandas.index' extension
cc -fno-strict-aliasing -O2 -pipe -fno-strict-aliasing -DNDEBUG -O2 -pipe -fno-strict-aliasing -fPIC -I/usr/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/numpy/core/include -Ipandas/src/klib -Ipandas/src -I/usr/local/include/python2.7 -c pandas/index.c -o build/temp.freebsd-9.0-RELEASE-amd64-2.7/pandas/index.o
cc: pandas/index.c: No such file or directory
cc: No input files specified
error: command 'cc' failed with exit status 1
```

but that does not have anything to do do with `--dry-run`, so I will close this.)
